Fields.DialogueText: Why the odd look, Rahal?
Officer Rahal?
Oh, my apologies, Captain...
What's going on?
Look... over... there...
What am I looking for? The mess hall is pretty packed.
Right... there...
What am I seeing?
Stand in my place. It will afford you a better view.
That's Wichita.
It is, Captain.
Sitting on the floor, in the middle of the mess hall.
You are correct, Captain.
Is she... what? Just watching everyone as they walk by?
That does appear to be the case.
Is that popcorn she has in her hand?
A bag of it, yes.
Where did she get a bag of popcorn?
Word on deck is that she has a popcorn machine in her quarters.
What?
She's an odd one.
Yes, I believe so, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Has anyone tried speaking with her?
Maybe I should speak with her.
I'll pay you five bucks to speak with her.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't believe so. I think they find her as strange as we do.
You're braver than I would be, Captain.
You'd have to up the price substantially before I'd consider such a proposition.
*ALARM*
She disappeared.
But did you see her? She looked this direction right before the alarm sounded.
That grin, and those green eyes of hers, they're...
Unnerving?
A little bit.
@BATTLE
You know, it's a little strange how you all stand around and stare at Wichita.
No stranger than her.
What's she up to?
Well, a little while ago, we found her lying on the deck, staring up at the sky.
That's not so strange.
Then she turned over and spent five minutes staring at the deck.

Fields.MenuText: Why?
For five minutes? You're not exaggerating?
I... don't... understand...

Fields.DialogueText: No idea. We were all placing bets on potential reasons. Care to join in?
I timed it. I knew no one would believe it otherwise.
You and me both, Captain.
What is she doing now?
She's had her eye on that flock of seagulls flying overhead. I think she's trying to lure them in.
What makes you think that?
She keeps throwing popcorn in their direction.
How is this a real thing that's happening aboard this ship?
Oh! Shh... look. One of the seagulls has settled on the railing next to her.
Wichita looks pleased.
Ecstatic, even.
And now she's--
Speaking to the seagull.
Of course. Is it taking popcorn from her hand?
That does appear to be the case, Captain.
*ALARM*
She disappeared again.
When it comes to battle, she is quite prompt.
We best be on our way as well.
@BATTLE
What's everyone doing huddled inside? You should soak up this nice weather while it lasts.
Clearly, you haven't been on deck recently.
What's happened? ...How many reports am I going to have to fill out?
Nothing so serious, Captain. It's just that...
*sigh*
What is Wichita doing now?
I think those seagulls have... imprinted on her. A whole flock of them have been following her around for the past half hour.
And making a mess on deck, no doubt.
Well, they do, but Wichita cleans up after them each time. Her dedication is impressive.
Still, none of the crew is too keen on testing their luck with the...
*ahem*
... firing squad outside.
Does she talk?
You hear her speak during battle.
Yes, I know. But to you, to the other officers, the crew. I can't remember hearing her say a word to anyone, other than that seagull.
She smiles at the crew as she walks by. To my knowledge, I haven't heard her engage anyone in conversation.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe she prefers speaking to animals?
Maybe she's shy?
Maybe she's just legitimately crazy?

Fields.DialogueText: I've heard of stranger behavior from Belles.
I don't think so, Captain. Shy people wouldn't people watch in the center of a room while eating popcorn.
Anything is possible, Captain.
*ALARM*
Sounds as if the seagulls are taking off.
Wichita's probably already at the bridge.
We shouldn't keep her waiting.
@BATTLE
Ha! Come on, Captain. Finish the story before we all have to get back to work.
All right, all right. Honestly, this friend of mine was so drunk he could hardly stand. I ended up having to...
... Wichita?
You don't mind if I sit and listen, do you?
Perfect. Thank you.
Please, continue on. Don't mind me.
Uh... well, so... where was I? My friend was drunk, and I knew there was no way he was going to make it home by himself, so I—
*munch*
Oh, my apologies. Where are my manners? Would anyone like some popcorn?
... You know what? Sure, I'll have some popcorn.
Oh, excellent. You're Officer Coltrain, aren't you? Here, I have an extra bag and everything. I just popped this batch five minutes ago.
... I'll admit, this is mighty good popcorn, Wichita.
Well, of course. What sort of Belle would I be if I gave a member of my crew subpar popcorn?

Fields.MenuText: Could we maybe table all popcorn-related discussions until after I finish my story?
What sort of Belle would you be?
... Could I have some?

Fields.DialogueText: My apologies, Captain – of course, continue with your story.
Trying to be clever, are you, Captain? I'll admit – I like my captains clever.
Well, of course, Captain! I'm happy to share.
So, your friend needed to get home, and you...
*ALARM*
No time to waste! See you all on the bridge!
Does she douse that popcorn in coffee? Is it pure caffeine?
Your guess is as good as mine, Captain.
@BATTLE
Enemy sighted off the starboard side!
@BATTLE
Wichita? You've been standing on that deck railing since we finished our last bout. Everything all right?
Mmm... there's a storm coming.

Fields.MenuText: You say spooky things from time to time, Wichita.
What makes you think that?
There isn't a cloud in the sky, Wichita.

Fields.DialogueText: If you think that's spooky, how would you classify your average Morgana encounter?
I can smell it. The wind coming in from the west - it smells like rain.
I didn't say it was going to rain on us in the next five minutes.
How large of a storm are we talking?
In line with an average summer storm in Kansas.
So, nothing too terrible?
Thunder, lightning, torrential rain, wind gusts reaching speeds in excess of 80 miles per hour.
That's your idea of an average summer storm in Kansas?
Well, sure. I didn't mention tornadoes, did I?
No...
Like I said. Average.
So... we should prepare the ship. That's what you're really telling me, right?
You're catching on, Captain.
... Why do you look so happy?
I like storms. Electrical currents passing overhead fascinate me greatly.
Of course they do.
Bone-chillingly terrifying?
Fair enough.
Rahal, this storm is something else. The waves nearly washed me overboard a few minutes ago.
You're not the only one. I pulled a few sailors from the brink earlier as well.
Is everyone present and accounted for? I don't want this storm getting the best of us on account of an oversight.
Everyone, except...
Except?
Look outside, Captain.
As if I could see anything through this downpour.
Right... there...
Is Wichita still standing on the railing of the ship?
She is.
Arms spread wide, staring up?
I'm afraid so, Captain.
Heh, as if we should expect anything less from her at this point.
Actually...
Hmm?
Let me preface this by saying that I, in no way, would ever believe this to be true.
There's nothing I look forward to more than a conversation which requires a preface...
Some of the men and women on board, Captain, they... well, they're of the mind that Wichita might be... a witch.

Fields.MenuText: Surely they're not serious.
As long as she's on our side, she could be the angel of death incarnate and I wouldn't care.

Fields.DialogueText: She's the spirit of this ship, Captain. Who knows what else she could be?
You might not, but some of the more God-fearing crew members aboard our ship might.
Well, you don't need to roll your eyes quite that far back in your head, Captain.
She's not a witch, Rahal. I'm confident of that much.
I'll pass your thoughts onto the crew... but I'm not sure it will do much to assuage their fears.
I'd appreciate you telling them what I said nonetheless.
*ALARM*
Well, isn't this just perfect weather for a battle?
@BATTLE
Captain, may I speak to you?
Wichita? Sure, if you don't mind my eating while you speak.
You know, you really ought to eat healthier food, Captain. It's important to take care of yourself.
Says the woman whom I've only ever seen eating popcorn.
When you're the spirit of a ship, you can get away with eating whatever you want.
How convenient.
I know.
How can I help you, Wichita?
I've noticed the crew has been acting strange... at least when they're near me. They've stopped making eye contact with me when I pass by.
Sometimes I hear them whisper my name at a distance. I'm wondering if you could shed some light on the situation.
You want the blunt answer?
I do.
Some of the crew have gotten it in their heads that you... might be a witch.
Hahahaha!

Fields.MenuText: You're taking this remarkably well.
You find their fear humorous?
You know, your laugh is a little... witchy.

Fields.DialogueText: Would you rather I take it poorly?
A little bit, I'll admit.
How's this? *cackle*
I should have known the Wizard of Oz references in my ensemble would cause grief eventually.
You...you actually did that?
I'm wearing ruby slippers, Captain. Should there have been any doubt in your mind?
That's a fair point.
So, what are you going to do about the crew?
*ALARM*
I'll just have to win them over. After the battle, of course.
I'm sure this will go over well.
@BATTLE
That's terrifying.
Muahaha...
All right, now you're overdoing it.
Enemy fleet spotted!
@BATTLE
What... happened... to the ship?
It's been covered, from bow to stern, with garlands made of popcorn.
Are those Christmas ornaments?
I think so, Captain.
Wichita!
You called, Captain?
Wha... what is all this?
Can't you tell? It's a winter wonderland.
One, that grin on your face is disconcerting. Two, why?

Fields.MenuText: It's nowhere near Christmas.
No other ships decorate this outlandishly for Christmas.
Where in the world did you get this much popcorn?

Fields.DialogueText: Christmas doesn't actually coincide with the birth of Christ, so even Christmas doesn't land on Christmas.
That's their loss, isn't it?
I grow corn in the lowermost part of the hull.
Wichita...
Listen. Any thoughts of my being a witch ought to be put to rest by my celebrating a thoroughly Christian holiday.
Even if some crew members don't celebrate Christmas, there's no better way of assuring them that I mean them no harm than by giving them gifts.
You really think that will work?
Officer Coltrain!
Yes, Wichita?
I heard you have a love for freshly baked apple pies. I had one made, just for you.
Gosh, Wichita, that... well, that's really swell of you.
Of course! Merry Christmas!
Merry Christmas to you too!
Unbelievable. You really have gifts for every person on board this ship?
I do. When I put my mind to something, there's not much capable of standing in my way.
I'll be sure to keep that in mind.
No, you don't.
You're right, I don't. But I really ought to consider doing so...
Morganas incoming! Battlestations everyone!
@BATTLE
*cheers* *applause*
Ah, Captain. I was wondering when the ruckus might draw your attention.
Do I want to know what's going on?
Well, Wichita's Christmas stunt has certainly turned the tide of the crew's opinion in her favor. She's their new favorite.
That doesn't tell me what's going on.
You're aware of Belles' ability to phase through solid objects, aren't you? Well, Wichita has been putting said abilities on display, much to the crew's delight.
You're kidding.
And for my next trick, I will stick my head through Officer Coltrain's chest!
Good Lord.
I will say, Captain, Wichita's... eccentricities aside, morale on the ship has never been higher.
Were you aware that, since "Christmas", she's taken the time to speak with every crewman and officer aboard this ship?
We had a half hour conversation earlier about my wife and children. She seems genuinely interested in their welfare, and my own. It's... odd.
Not long ago, she hardly said a word to anyone. How is this the same Belle?
Your guess is as good as mine, Captain. But as long as the crew remains happy and we keep winning battles, I don't feel much need to question it.
Do you feel differently?
Not necessarily, Rahal. But... I would like to figure out what makes her tick.
Wichita? What are you doing back here in the galley?
Making caramel corn.
I should have guessed.
You seem a little more low-key than you have the last few times I've seen you.
It's not always easy to maintain the level of enthusiasm I've become known for recently.
Funny you should mention that.
Is it now?
I like to get a feel for my crew, Wichita. It's important to know how everyone operates. But you... you're a mystery to me.
I'm just a simple Kansas girl.
Heh.
Yeah, that "heh" undercuts everything that came before it.
It isn't far from the truth.
What do you mean?
I have lived a sheltered life. Bear in mind that, until very recently, I was asleep, dormant in the walls of this ship.
What of it?
Consider being in my shoes, Captain. Imagine if you'd spent the whole of your life unable to move or speak. You could only watch, only think.
Then imagine that, in the blink of an eye, you were free. You could move at will, and speak your mind. That the whole of the world was before you.
What would you do?
Honestly? I wouldn't know where to start.
I had that difficulty as well, when I first awoke. Along with the added complication of not knowing how long I would persist in this present form.
After all, I awoke without warning. We all did. What's to say that we won't one day fall asleep just as quickly?
N-nothing, I guess...
It became clear to me that I must take nothing for granted. That I must fully experience everything this world has to offer to the best of my ability.
Not only experience, but understand. I want to know the world and how it works.
If I do fall asleep one day, I don't want to look back at this time and regret having wasted any of it.
So sitting in the middle of the mess hall watching everyone? Or communing with the seagulls outside? That was... experiencing the world? Understanding it?
It was. I wanted to start small, to ease into these experiences. Use my eyes to see, my ears to hear.
And you've been working your way up from there.
I have.  Watching the men and women aboard this ship, I gained an affection for them. It seemed only natural that I do my part to encourage and support them.
It's quite the massive undertaking.
I'm well aware. Hence my need to get away and conserve my energy from time to time.
*yawn*
*ALARM*
Think you have enough energy for a small skirmish?
I think I can muster it.
@BATTLE
Enemy approaching, dead ahead!
@BATTLE
Great work out there, as usual, Wichita.
Wichita?
Look at my scout plane out there. I could watch it for days.
Ellis should have headed back this way minutes ago. He does like taking his sweet time returning to the ship after a battle.
Wouldn't you?
Would you?
I would.
Think of the freedom afforded to you by flight, with nothing tying you to the ground.
Last I knew, you were capable of floating, Wichita.
I have my own ties to the ground beneath me.
Still, aviation as a whole is a favorite subject of mine. Ellis told me he would teach me all there was to know regarding aviation technology.

Fields.MenuText: Is that a fact? I'm sure the mechanics on board would be delighted to have your help.
Ellis does like to find creative ways of shirking his duties.
What isn't a favorite subject of yours?

Fields.DialogueText: When I have a strong enough command of the subject, I will be delighted to give it.
Don't worry, Captain–I'll make sure he sees to his responsibilities.
... Waste management?
You don't have to wait out here with me, Captain. I'll get back to my duties once Ellis lands.
Now that I've started watching... it is kind of relaxing.
Aha! Well then, here, take a seat. Even captains need breaks sometimes.
Don't mind if I do.
Really?
Actually, sewer systems can be quite fascinating.
We've got Morganas incoming!  Fly my pretties, fly!
@BATTLE
You know, Wichita, when you hang upside down from the railing like that, it can cause others a bit of a fright.
Oh, whom have I frightened?
Passengers aboard the last four ships we've passed. I've received many calls.
*cackle* ... All right, all right. I didn't mean to cause any undue emotional distress.
Just what were you doing, anyway?
Getting a better look at the coral reefs we're passing over.
This is my first time in the Mediterranean, you know. The abundance of life in these warm waters is fascinating.
You could always take a dive  to get a closer look, you know.
Seeing me leap from the deck surely won't upset passing ships.
We would do it right – anchor the ship, let any of the crew who'd like a swim dive along with you.
There are no Morganas in the immediate area, and we have some extra time before we're supposed to arrive in Barcelona.
And I can't let you be the only person on board interested in the crew's morale.
I like this side of you, Cap. Won't you dive along with us?

Fields.MenuText: It might be better if I acted as lifeguard.
While I appreciate your consideration, I have work to see to.
I'll be the first one in the water!

Fields.DialogueText: Considering some of the officers we have on board, that's probably not a bad idea.
Rain check, then? Your morale is just as important as that of everyone else on board.
Not if I beat you there!
Go tell Officer Rahal the plan. He'll help you pass the word along.
You've got it!
Sure, Wichita. Rain check.
So, what do you think of Barcelona, Wichita?
It's so beautiful! I want to shrink all the architecture down and take it with me in my pocket wherever I go.
I'm sure the Barcelonans won't even notice the disappearance of their historical landmarks.
*cackle* No, I think not.
Captain, some of us are headed into town. Can we pick you up anything?
Hold on one moment, I'll go with you.
I heard about this place up the road that has a reputation for serving the best tapas on the planet.
I have no idea what a tapa even is, but I know I want to try it.

Fields.MenuText: Trust me, Coltrain, you're in for a treat.
You don't know what a tapa is?
I'm more of a dessert-person myself. Crema catalana is the way to go.

Fields.DialogueText: Now I'm even more excited.
Don't poke fun, Captain. It's not as if I spent much time travelling the world before the war.
Crema catalana? Can we have that after we have tapas?
Wichita, can we pick you up anything while we're out? Would you like us to bring you some of Coltrain's infamous tapas?
I was hoping to work on my Spanish while we were here. Do you think you could find me some sort of Spanish guidebook?
Sure, Wichita. That's not a bad idea.
*ALARM*
Looks as if your tapas will have to wait, Coltrain.
Of course...
@BATTLE
Mucho gusto! Me llamo Wichita.
Sí, Wichita.
Whi...chi...tah.
I see Wichita is charming the Barcelonans.
She's going to wear herself out.
You think?
I do. She's determined to meet as many people as she can, but you should see her the few times there's actually a lull in the crowd.
She looks as if she might fall asleep on the spot.
And yet, her friendliness is probably for the best. Helps improve the public's opinion of the Belles and the Protection Force.
Might even do something to improve relations between the United States and Spain.
Still, we can't let her wear herself out so thoroughly that she can't face the Morganas.
Look sharp, Captain. Some reporters are headed her way. What do you want to do?

Fields.MenuText: Let them speak with her. Like you said, we should be in the game of improving public opinion.
We should intervene. Wichita is tired enough as it is.
Grab Officer Diaz. Wichita's Spanish ability doesn't extend far past "mucho gusto", at this point.

Fields.DialogueText: You've got it, Captain.
I'll go pull her away from the crowd, Captain.
Not a bad thought, Captain. I'll track her down.
*ALARM*
What timing. Rahal, keep an eye on Wichita during the battle, would you? Make sure she stays upright.
Of course, Captain.
@BATTLE
Wichita!
Captain?
Goodness, were you sleeping? I'm sorry for waking you.
How could you tell?
I can see where a pillow's fabric was pressed up against your cheek.
Heh heh heh... I'm the soul of professionalism, aren't I?
I'm just glad you're getting a little shut eye now and then.
What's going on?
Ah, yes. You received this letter.
A letter? I've... I've never received a letter before. Can I see it?
Well, it's your letter. So I'd say yes.
I'm going to use the utmost care while opening the envelope. I have every intention of keeping this letter for the rest of my life.
It's your letter – do with it as you wish.
What does it say?
It's from one of the reporters who interviewed me earlier. He's inviting me to a gala to be held downtown tomorrow evening.
It's in support of the war effort. Looks as if it will be quite the party.
Well, that's exciting! Your first letter, followed by your first gala...
Oh.
At times I forget you can't leave the ship.
It's all right.
Is it? Be truthful - you would have liked to have gone.
I won't deny it, but I have responsibilities aboard this ship. Even if I could leave it for an extended period of time, it  doesn't mean doing so would be wise.
*ALARM*
Come on now, Captain. We have work to do.
@BATTLE
Wichita, we're about to...
Woah.
Hmm? What is it, Captain?
Your quarters... I feel as if I've stepped back into Barcelona.
I did go a little all out with decorating, didn't I?
A little bit. Not that these flags and fans and flowers are unwelcome... it's that there are... a lot of them.
I'll admit, I can indulge from time to time.
Trust me, I've picked up on your tendency to revel in firing all the ammunition during battles.
*cackle*
Any idea where this indulgence comes from?
I have a theory. While I did not technically live through the great depression and the dust bowl, those events greatly affected my namesake.
Nothing was spent unless it had to be spent. Needs regularly went unmet, to say nothing of wants.
The world seems to be recovering.
As is my namesake, for which I am grateful.
Personally, I've discovered that I have some difficulty finding the middle ground between spending nothing and spending everything.

Fields.MenuText: That... makes some sense.
That's a habit you really ought to curtail before it gets out of control.
I suppose that explains "Christmas" as well, doesn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: You think so? That's good to hear, I suppose.
I don't disagree, but I might need some assistance in the process.
I hadn't thought of that, but now that you mention it...yes, it does.
Just bear in mind, we're heading to New Orleans now. Some horde of Morganas keeps terrorizing the coast, and Command wants us on hand to defend it.
If you keep up the souvenir buying at this rate, you'll very quickly find yourself without a place to sleep.
New Orleans? I've always wanted to travel to New Orleans...
*ALARM*
Get us through this battle, and you'll be able to see it with your own two eyes.
These Morganas won't stand a chance.
@BATTLE
Bonjour, New Orleans!
Practicing your French now, are you?
No, no, not so much. Now, if we were to visit a French coastal town like Cannes or Saint-Tropez...
We've barely arrived in New Orleans, and already you're dreaming about some other place?
I dream about all places, Captain. But of course, I am thrilled to be here in New Orleans.
Just look at this place! The colors, the culture...and do I hear music in the distance? I think I hear music in the distance.
I've never heard live music before...
Listen – we have supplies we need to unload. If you help the crew, I'll see about getting an accordion player and a couple trumpet players to come this way.
I'm sure the crew would appreciate some music as well.
Really? That would be perfect, Captain.
*ALARM*
It's a shame we can't have a few jazz musicians on board during the fight. Can you imagine battling while music plays in the background?

Fields.MenuText: It would make for an entertaining fight, that's for certain.
I think that music would prove a little too distracting for the crew.
I'm not sure the jazz musicians would be too pleased by the situation...

Fields.DialogueText: Someday, maybe...
Practically speaking... you're probably right.
Oh, I'd make sure they were confident not a hair on their heads would be harmed.
Ready?
Let's get to it. I'll fight Morganas anywhere!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
*trumpet blare*
*applause*
Moriah, while I know Wichita clearly appreciates your presence, don't feel compelled to stay if there are other places you need to be.
Oh, I don't mind in the least, Captain. It's a real pleasure putting on a show for you all.
Not to mention, now I can tell all my friends I've spoken face to face with an honest-to-God Belle.
Moriah's going to teach me how to play the trumpet.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure learning how to play a musical instrument is high on your list of things to experience.
Are you sure that's the best use of your time?
Must she?

Fields.DialogueText: It's number six on the list, in fact.
Learning to play a musical instrument has all sorts of practical applications, you know. It teaches discipline, trains the ear...
She absolutely must.
How would you like to come over to my house for some tea, Wichita? It's just across the way–you can see it from here. Captain, you're welcome to come as well.
I have some jazz records I think you'd enjoy very much.
Well...
Have I misspoken?
No, no, Moriah. Were I able to come, I happily would. But I'm tied to the ship.
Tied to the...?
Hmm...that can't be easy.
*ALARM*
...Don't worry about it, Moriah.
Captain, are you ready?
...Of course, Wichita.
@BATTLE
All right, all right, I get the picture.
I'm not accustomed to seeing you on the dock without a crowd of people surrounding you, Wichita.
The people of New Orleans have been very kind, but I think most of them are disappointed when they see me that I'm not actually, you know, New Orleans.
Heh.
What's going on in that head of yours? It's not often I see you facing the ocean when there's a city at your back.
I'm trying to properly prioritize my thoughts and feelings.
How is that going?
Middling success, thus far.
Care to communicate the gist of those thoughts and feelings?
I know I'm lucky. So many ships all over the world – the vast majority – didn't awaken. I did, and I have so much freedom as a result.
But this ship keeps you on a short leash.
It does. I've tried to put that out of my mind, to experience the many things that were within my reach.
But I want to see cities. Not just their coastlines, but their downtowns. I want to see Wichita, my own namesake, with my own eyes.
I want to be able to leave this dock, walk across the way, and have tea at Moriah's house, if I so desire.
How strong is the force keeping you within range of the ship?
I'm not sure... Belles don't typically make a habit of testing such things.
But you're a Belle in pursuit of all understanding.
... I suppose I am, aren't I?
*ALARM*
After this battle... we'll discuss.
I'm looking forward to it.
@BATTLE
This is as far as I can go.
Ten meters from the ship?
More or less.
How does it feel?
Like I'm at the end of my rope, figuratively speaking. I don't think I could describe it in more concrete terms.
Can you take a step?
Uh...
Can you lift up your leg?
... Yes.
Now, put it down.
You put it down in the same spot.
I tried to take a step forward, but it didn't take!

Fields.MenuText: Try it again.
Why don't you try running?
Why don't you try cartwheeling?

Fields.DialogueText: Only if you can give me a decent reason why trying the same thing might have a different result.
Because I'd rather not needlessly exhaust myself.
Trust me, I'm no gymnast.
Listen, Captain. As is, I don't think walking is the way to go. If a Belle could merely walk away from her ship, we would have been doing so long before this.
*ALARM*
Fair enough. After this battle, we'll think of some... more creative possibilities.
That's what I like to hear.
@BATTLE
Thought so.
Captain, you're looking a little... damp.
Things with Wichita going well?
Swimming was next on our list of ways Wichita might outdistance her tether to the ship. We didn't have much luck.
Captain...
You sound as if you have reservations, Rahal.
In a manner of speaking.
Well, out with them. Once I'm dried off, I have to run to a meeting.
It's not that I have any problem with Wichita, of course.
Of course.
It's just that, these experiments – or whatever you wish to call them – of yours, they're demanding quite a bit of your time.
As it is my responsibility to support you, Captain, I want to make sure you're not feeling as if you're being stretched too thin.
I appreciate your concern, Rahal. If you perceive that, at some point in the future, I'm exhausting myself needlessly, please set me straight.
But I'm fine. Wichita has gone out of her way to support everyone aboard this ship. Aiding her now is the least I can do in return.
As that is the case, I wish to volunteer my assistance in the matter as well, if you think I could be of any help.

Fields.MenuText: That's very considerate of you, Rahal. I'll be sure to let her know.
I need you doing what you do best, Rahal. Your work is vital to the ship.
Rahal... are you finally warming up to Wichita?

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain.
Of course, Captain.
I will admit to no such thing.
Rahal! There you are. Here.
Why did you just hand me three starfish?
Because you said your kids loved them. Remember?
I did, didn't I?
Thank you, Wichita.
Of course. Now you two better get to the bridge - we have some Morganas headed this way.
Thanks for the heads up, Wichita.
Of course!
See, she isn't so bad.
*sigh* I know...
@BATTLE
Heh.
Morganas chasing a civilian vessel!  All hands to battlestations!
@BATTLE
Captain!
Oh, there you are, Wichita. You know, I had another idea we might try...
I did, too – it came to me during the battle!
Mine did as well. You think we had the same idea?
I bet we did... should we try saying our ideas at the same time?
Heh, sure. Why not?
All right... one, two, three!
We should see if your range is extended during battle!
You should fire me out of one of the guns! ... Oh.

Fields.MenuText: Tell me you didn't just say what I thought I heard you say.
No. Under no circumstances is that a thing that's going to happen aboard a ship of mine.
I guess we aren't quite as in sync as you might have hoped.

Fields.DialogueText: If you heard me say you should fire me out of one of the guns...
Oh, come on, Captain! What's the worst that could happen?
Well, it was worth a shot.
I think that if we were to come at the tether with enough force, I'd be able to break through!
I'm sorry, but I refuse to gain a reputation as "that captain who let their Belle fire herself out of one of the guns."
Fine... Captain Killjoy.
Captain, we've received word that the Morgana horde is headed this direction. We should begin preparations.
Of course, Rahal. Wichita?
Let's get to it, Captain.
*sigh*
I can think of five equally terrible possibilities at this very moment.
*ALARM*
Command wasn't kidding when they called this group of Morganas a horde.
No. The term is quite...apt.
You think you're up to the task, Wichita?
Well, I might use up all the ammunition we have on board... but I think I can take them.
It looks as if the horde is planning on attacking in two waves. Please try to pace your ammunition consumption, if at all possible.
Wichita?
I have an idea.
You will not fire yourself out of one of the guns during this battle.
I know, I know. Don't worry.
If I ever try anything like that, I'll wait until we're not in the middle of a fight.
How reassuring.
So, what's your plan?
I'm going to keep it under wraps for the moment. It shouldn't affect the battle - just do your captainly thing, Cap.
We need you on the bridge, Captain.
You sure you're ready for this, Wichita?
I might not be a battleship, but I'm sure I can give these Morganas a run for their money.
All right. Wave one, let's go.
@BATTLE
Wave two, everyone! Let's get to it!
@BATTLE
Great work, Rahal. I'm a little surprised we made it out of that one, to be honest.
I'm just happy we did.
Have you seen Wichita? That battle had to have taken a lot out of her.
Not since the battle ended, now that I think about it.
Wichita? I saw her head down toward the docks, not long after we made it back to port. She... didn't look great.
Is that a fact?
Do we have a problem, Captain?
I'm not sure, but I'm going to find out.
- A Little While Later -
Why, Captain! I was just coming to find you.
Moriah, have you seen...
Wichita? She's sitting on my porch swing, there.
Wichita... you made it all the way here!
You... look awful.
Well, it's a pleasure to see you too, Cap. Don't rock the porch swing! I'm enjoying my tea.
How did you do it? How did you make it here?
I had a hunch that, if I were to take enough damage during battle, whatever force typically keeps me bound to the ship might be somewhat weaker than usual.
Of course, I'm also somewhat weaker than usual...
That's why I was coming to find you, Captain.
I... might need some help getting back to the ship. I barely have enough energy to lift this teacup to my mouth.
That being said, Moriah, this is the most delightful tea I've ever tasted. You know what it tastes like, Captain?
Freedom?
I was going to say ginger and cardamom, but I do think there's a hint of freedom in there, as well.
You're welcome at my house any time, Wichita. Next time, maybe you'll even be able to set foot inside.
I have my eye on that sofa in your living room, Moriah. You know, I've never sat on a sofa before.
All right, I think it's time to get you back to the ship. Moriah, thank you.
Of course, Captain. It was my pleasure.
Zzzzzzzzzz...
Oh, good grief.
Great, more Morganas...
@BATTLE
Is Ellis still flying around out there?
He knows I like watching.
Glad to see you on your feet again for the battle. How are you feeling?
Still a little weak, but I'm no longer falling asleep mid-sentence, so that's an improvement.
Maybe you should run any off-ship excursions past me in the future?
I suppose that's fair.
Ellis really shouldn't do loop de loops in the scout plane.
But look at him go! Over and over and over. I love it.
Hmm? What do you have in your hands, there?
Just a teacup.
Wichita... you took one of Moriah's teacups?
Oh, she said I could.
What is it now? Your good luck charm?
Not anything so superstitious. It's just a reminder.
Of your time with Moriah?
That, and that this tether won't hold me forever.
One day, I'll be able to set foot inside Moriah's house. One day, I'll be able to visit my namesake.
One day, nothing will be withheld from my grasp.
What is it?
You remember your tendency toward indulgence?
You think I should resist these desires?
I think you should temper them. Overindulgence doesn't look good on anyone.
There is some truth there.
Will you help me, Captain? If I'm running amok, you will set me straight, won't you?

Fields.MenuText: As your captain, I do believe that's my responsibility.
As long as you promise to do the same for me.

Fields.DialogueText: I think you might have a point there.
Well, of course, Captain. We'll look out for one another.
